Hollywood, FL 28/3/2012 I tried them for the first time last friday. It was my first time eating Indian food, and might I say, the food was DELICIOUS. The naan bread is to die for! It's soft and doughy, cooked to perfection. I like that the orders are large, so I left feeling super content. I order the eggplant vegetarian dish and my friend ordered a spicy chicken dish. My server was kind, attentive, and recommended the dish that I ordered.
While waiting for my food I was delighted to watch some Indian music videos. Nice entertainment. The restaurant is small and it had a home-y feel to it. It was nice and comforting.
I would recommend that you go if you're in the area. It's worth it!

Davie, FL 7/1/2012 3 Check-ins Here This resto is very near and dear to my heart, for it was at Indian Chillies that I discovered I love Indian food.
Okay, so is place isn't perfect - yes, the service can be slow, but they are always attentive. The owner Jasmine is extremely friendly, always greets us when go in, and remembers our orders. She has also pushed us into new realms of deliciousness, one day telling us, "you don't want samosas, you want samosa chaat". Guess what? Turns out she was right =]
The nann is outrageous - crispy on the bottom, fluffy in the middle, buttery on the top. I like coming for the buffet - usually there is butter chicken, plus a goat dish and a chickpea dish, with basmati rice, nann and other sides. I think it is the best bang for your buck.

Pembroke Pines, FL 17/9/2011 I'm being gracious but they were nice and the food was decent and even more so very fairly priced for Indian food. Worldwide I would definitely give it more of a 3.
They are small and have this weird bright green decor that screams mom and pop but I don't mind. Yes, the servers wear t-shirts and the Haitian lady 's shirt was a bit stained but since the food was relatively cheap what do you expect? Surely not Cheesecake Factory servers dressed in all white.
They are very practical. It's refreshing actually. Props. The cups and silverware are already on the table and they drop off a pitcher of water if you want water which works for me and reminds me of Korea and China except I still had to tip and the price was still more. Anyways so it was busy because it was Friday night, Groupon offer, a lot of Indian tables, watever the reason.
The samosa was good. $4 for 2. The sauce was a bit strong and distinctive so I didn't use it. My bf ordered the Tikka Masala. It tasted more tomato based and I thought it was supposed to be sweeter bc of the coconut but I am probably mistaken as I've only ate Indian food 3xs prior to this. It did have flavor and wasn't bland.
My Korma Chicken had bones which I was a bit surprised and kind of didn't like picking through but it was flavored. As I said before this is not the best Indian restaurant but it's surely not bland, reasonably priced and the service is pretty good for a restaurant it's size and ambiance if you know what I mean (I don't mean to sound harsh or anything).

Miramar, FL 24/2/2011 For being such a destination for great chefs and foodies, Miami and the South Florida area in general is lacking in certain cuisines. I have found it challenging to find a good, basic, fresh, simple Indian menu.
Today, in Hollywood, I found one.
Let's get the few bruises out of the way. The location, decor, and bathrooms are very simple and unassuming. If you need those things to be updated and luxurious, you may be disappointed. However, if, like me, you take simplicity like this as a sign that the energies are being spent on the food, then you are in luck, because Indian Chillies does a great job.
A friend and I enjoyed their lunch buffet. All of your usual suspects were present, hot and fresh naan made to order (not placed on the buffet table), delicious and well-chilled chutney, tamarind, mint, and yogurt dips and sauces, Chicken Tikka Masala (saltier than I'm normally used to, and I found that to be a plus today), Palak Paneer with unusually large slices of green pepper as part of the deal, Haleem, Channa Masala, and your standards of rice and boiled potato.
The service was simple and casual. There was a giant plasma TV tuned into Indian soap operas with surtitles.
On the way out, our lovely server, multi-tasker told me that there is also a $4.99 breakfast buffet on the weekends. I may have to return just to see what exactly happens at an Indian breakfast buffet.
"I was the first Indian model to have a career in Paris, Milan and New York. I am the first one to admit I was a novelty." -Padma Lakshmi
Good Indian food may be a novelty down here in the tropics. I am glad I live close to this place!

Hollywood, FL 27/2/2011 1 Check-in Here My husband and I went to Indian Chilies for dinner last Friday night. Typically I am used to buffet style, but for dinner, you must order off the menu (not bad, just an FYI). We arrived around 7pm, and the restaraunt was mostly empty (maybe 3 other occupied tables).
A really nice woman greeted us (looked like the manager/owner) and I told her it was our first time, so she explained some of the dishes to us, and gave us recommendations. We ordered simple drinks, and I had the Chicken Tikka Masala, my husband had the Butter Chicken. The chicken dishes came in their own little pots, and they initially gave us 1 dish of rice between both of us, but when we asked, they brought another dish of rice. Another waitress explained that they bring one to start, but each meal does come with it's own rice dish.
We also ordered garlic naan which was AMAZING, along with the yogurt dipping sauce. All the food was DELICIOUS, and served quickly. The only thing my husband sort of wishes they had was a side of vegetables included with the dish, instead of just the chicken and white rice. Just another FYI, the Butter Chicken was not spicy at all, but the Chick Tikka Masala had a kick even though I ordered it mild. If you are new to Indian food, at least you can know to expect it.
Honestly, this is a no frills place with great food. I loved it, and will definitely be back. We want to go back and try the lunch buffet so we can get a better idea of what Indian dishes to order in the future.
p.s. We really enjoyed the Indian Television station playing on the big screen tv!

Miami Beach, FL 15/10/2010 First off let me qualify my rating, I am giving this restaurant 5 stars on the food and I am adjusting this scale to Indian food in the Dade and Broward Markets. Having come from the West Coast my palate for indian food was cultured in San Francisco, Seattle and Vancouver with some occasional binges in Britan, not saying I am an expert food critic but I know good Indian. Moving to Miami 8 years ago was a culture food shock to me. Things have gotten a million times better overall here but living in Dade, Indian options for the most part are either really bad or good but 50 bucks a person. Broward has proven to be a lot better and this particular restaurant reminds me of eating in an Indian Diner in the Tenderloin in San Francisco.
The silverware looks like it came from a high school cafeteria, the decorations are old and faded, the napkins are so thin that you need 5 of them to wipe the curry from your face but man I didnt want to leave. The 60 inch flat screen playing Bollywood in HD immediately sucked me in and then I opened the menu and felt like I was back in San Francisco. Too many choices and they all sounded great, I was bummed there was only two of us because there were at least 5 things I saw right off that I wanted.
I got partway through the menu and immediately passed judgment when I saw what appeared to be a chinese section to the menu with chow mein and a couple other Chinese sounding items, I thought here is an attempt to please these Broward people that know nothing about Indian. The woman that runs the restaurant assured me that Chinese food is very popular in India and this is the Indian version, she just got back from India and it is still all the rage. That was enough for me, my date agreed, we ordered the Chilie Chicken Chow Mein and Mutten Curry (exact names a little different). I have not had Indian Chinese before but I am a fan, the curry was excellent as well. For naans we went with the garlic and regular naan, both were very good.
We quickly both went into a food coma and got again sucked in to the Bollywood. Tons of leftovers in front of us we finally decided it was time to go. Total check, $28. I will probably be back next Thursday.
2 minuses -- No beer, we need to convince them that BYOB is ok. I ordered very spicy, could have been spicer (I do have a high toerance though)
Back to enjoying my leftovers, still great cold!

Pittsburgh, PA 27/9/2011 I went for the lunch buffet.
First, I agree with another reviewer that this place is not well marked. Had my GPS not led me into the parking lot and then walking up and down the sidewalk, I would have missed it. There is next to no signage.
Second, I also agree with the ambiance, i.e., there is none. Doesn't matter to me, but may matter to you.
Third, as a buffet, I was disappointed with the lack of variety. They had two veggie dishes (chic peas, and mixed veggies -- maybe it was supposed to be cauliflower and potatoes) and two chicken dishes (looked like a cream sauce and a curry sauce). Nothing marked. Minimal condiments (no pickles). Lots of starch: plain rice, fried rice and noodles. Single appetizer was alu (potato) samosa. Plain salad. Gulab jamun. Nan is brought to the table (the nan was tasty!)
The flavor was OK. Bland, nothing special or exotic. Nothing spicy, though there was some chili paste available.

Okay then I was sitting around with my menu waiting for someone to get my order for like 10 minutes...the guy who greeted us sat in a corner with two other overweight Indian people while a Haitian lady (the waitress) kept on spraying tables and going in and out of the kitchen. So I asked her if I could get my order please...she seemed annoyed and she was def not waitress material; I could hardly hear what she was saying and she didn't know anything about the food on the menu. I had to walk over to the other table to ask them what chicken 65 was.
I placed my order and waited and waited for about 20 minutes. In this time, I watched bollywood dance songs. It was kind of a dull environment because there was no other activity going on, the two other guests were blah too. Anyway, after 20 mins the girl brought out my brother's coke can and ONE naan. I was like ??? how does that even help. The food kept coming out in this weird order, like then we got one bowl of rice. Finally after five minutes, food came out in small copper dishes. We were like, "ahh finally". We had chicken manchurian and chicken tikka masala. The chicken manchurian had no spice at all; it just tasted like tomato paste with a touch of black pepper!! We asked for mild, not no flavor. The chicken tikka masala was slightly better but still below average. The sauce was watery. Between us three people, we did not even finish two dishes (and the dishes were small sizes). The best part of the dinner was the naan; it had a good fluffy texture and was buttered like i requested.
But the naan was not enough to redeem the meal. I feel bad giving such a low rating because i did like several things; ex. their attention to sanitation, the main host guy, and that we got real plates and utensils....but the mumbling bored waitress, inattentive management, dull atmosphere, and mediocre food make it unlikely that i'll ever eat here again.
